IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 16414 S0926-860X(17)30449-0 10.1016/j.apcata.2017.09.020 S0926-860X(15)30228-3 10.1016/j.apcata.2015.10.051 Fig. 1 Gas chromatogram for phenanthrene hydrocracking reaction. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Mass spectra results for HP-5 column. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Mass spectra results for HP-1 column (new experiment). Fig. 3 Corrigendum to Improving the selectivity in hydrocracking of phenanthrene over mesoporous Al-SBA-15 based Fe-W catalysts by enhancing mesoporosity and acidity [ Applied Catalysis A: General 510 (2016) 98–109] Jonatan R. Restrepo-Garcia Víctor G. Baldovino-Medrano Sonia A. Giraldo Centro de Investigaciones en Catálisis (@CICATUIS), Escuela de Ingeniería Química Cra 27, Calle 9, Universidad Industrial de Santander (UIS) Bucaramanga, Colombia Centro de Investigaciones en Catálisis (@CICATUIS), Escuela de Ingeniería Química Cra 27, Calle 9, Universidad Industrial de Santander (UIS) Bucaramanga Colombia The authors regret that there is a mistake in the article which is explained below: Note of Correction to: Improving the selectivity in hydrocracking of phenanthrene over mesoporous Al-SBA-15 based Fe–W catalysts by enhancing mesoporosity and acidity. Applied Catalysis A: General 510 (2016) 98–109 The present note of correction refers to the paper: “ Improving the selectivity in hydrocracking of phenanthrene over mesoporous Al-SBA-15 based Fe–W catalysts by enhancing mesoporosity and acidity ”. In our work, we reported the formation of trans-stilbene by the selective hydrocracking of phenanthrene in accordance to GC-MS results ( Figs. 1 and 2). However, we have further repeated GC-MS analyses by changing the column for mass spectrometry measurements from the original HP-5 column to an HP-1 column; which is the same employed for GC analyses of reaction products [1]. By doing so, we found that 9,10-dihydrophenanthrene and not trans-stilbene was one of the reaction products of the performed reaction ( Fig. 3). It is worth mentioning that the larger HP-1column allowed for a better resolution of peaks in chromatograms. Moreover, mass spectrometry is a technique that depends directly on the chromatographic patterns used to a satisfactory identification of compounds. 9,10-dihydrophenanthrene is an intermediary of ring-opening reactions ascribed to phenanthrene hydrocracking [2]. Concerning the formation of trans-stilbene, it has been reported that its formation requires a high conversion of phenanthrene. The latter is attained at more severe reaction conditions [3] than those used in our research [1] Considering the above, it must be admitted that no ring-opening was truly evidenced in our original report [1]. Hence the presented catalysts did not actually lead to phenanthrene hydrocracking under the studied reaction conditions: 623 K and 11 MPa. Despite this mistake, the basic premise behind the work does not change. Particularly, we synthesized sulfided Fe-W catalysts over enhanced mesoporosity SBA-15 materials by adding 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (swelling agent), and modified with aluminum at different Si/Al molar ratios (10, 25, and 40). These materials possessed Brönsted acid sites which promoted the formation of 9,10-dihydrophenanthrene; which even if it is not a hydrocracking product by itself, hints to a development of the hydrocracking of phenanthrene. The same was not observed for a commercial sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst which only possesses Lewis acid sites in its support [4]. The authors would like to apologise for any inconvenience caused. DOI of original article: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apcata.2015.10.051 References [1] J.R. Restrepo-Garcia V.G. Baldovino-Medrano S.A. Giraldo Applied Catalysis A: General 510 2016 98 109 [2] M. Chareonpanich Z.-G. Zhang A. Tomita Energy & Fuels 10 1996 927 931 [3] S.C. Korre M.T. Klein R.J. Quann Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research 36 1997 2041 2050 [4] C. Contescu J. Jagiello J.A. Schwarz J.M.B.D.P.A.J.G. Poncelet P. Grange Studies in Surface Science and Catalysis 1995 Elsevier 237 252
